diabetes: A chronic condition where the body cannot regulate blood sugar properly.
hypertension: A condition where the blood pressure in the arteries is consistently elevated.
asthma: A respiratory condition marked by spasms in the bronchi of the lungs.
cancer: A disease caused by uncontrolled division of abnormal cells in a part of the body.
stroke: A medical emergency where blood flow to the brain is interrupted.
depression: A mental health disorder characterized by persistent sadness and lack of interest.
anxiety: A feeling of worry, nervousness, or unease about something with an uncertain outcome.
heart failure: A condition where the heart cannot pump blood efficiently.
COPD: A group of lung diseases that block airflow and make breathing difficult.
tuberculosis: An infectious disease that mainly affects the lungs.
HIV: A virus that attacks the immune system and can lead to AIDS.
malaria: A mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Plasmodium parasites.
pneumonia: Infection that inflames air sacs in one or both lungs.
hepatitis B: A liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus.
hepatitis C: A liver infection caused by the hepatitis C virus.
migraine: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches.
arthritis: Inflammation of one or more joints, causing pain and stiffness.
lupus: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues.
multiple sclerosis: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves.
Crohn's disease: A type of inflammatory bowel disease that may affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract.
ulcerative colitis: A chronic, inflammatory bowel disease that causes inflammation in the digestive tract.
obesity: A condition of excessive body fat that increases the risk of health problems.
anemia: A condition where there is a lack of red blood cells or hemoglobin.
thyroid disorder: A medical condition that affects the function of the thyroid gland.
chronic kidney disease: The gradual loss of kidney function over time.
epilepsy: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of seizures.
autism: A developmental disorder that affects communication and behavior.
dementia: A group of symptoms affecting memory, thinking, and social abilities.
Alzheimer's disease: A progressive disease that destroys memory and other mental functions.
Parkinson's disease: A nervous system disorder that affects movement.
COVID-19: An infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
influenza: A contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses.
eczema: A condition that makes the skin red, inflamed, and itchy.
psoriasis: A skin disease marked by red, itchy, scaly patches.
gout: A form of arthritis characterized by severe pain, redness, and tenderness in joints.
GERD: A digestive disorder where stomach acid irritates the food pipe lining.
bronchitis: Inflammation of the lining of bronchial tubes.
endometriosis: A painful disorder where tissue similar to the uterus lining grows outside the uterus.
meningitis: Inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord.
sepsis: A life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to infection.
leukemia: A type of cancer that affects blood and bone marrow.
lymphoma: Cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system.
myocardial infarction: Commonly known as a heart attack, caused by reduced blood flow to the heart.
angina: Chest pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscles.
atrial fibrillation: An irregular and often rapid heart rate.
valvular heart disease: Damage or defect in one of the four heart valves.
sinusitis: Inflammation or swelling of the tissue lining the sinuses.
otitis media: An infection of the middle ear.
urinary tract infection: An infection in any part of the urinary system.
constipation: A condition in which bowel movements are infrequent or hard to pass.
diarrhea: Frequent loose, watery stools that may be a sign of infection or digestive upset.
fever: An elevated body temperature, often due to infection.
nausea: A feeling of sickness with an inclination to vomit.
vomiting: Forcible voluntary or involuntary emptying of stomach contents through the mouth.
fatigue: A feeling of constant tiredness or weakness.
rash: A noticeable change in the texture or color of your skin.
back pain: Discomfort or pain felt in the upper, middle, or lower back.
chest pain: A discomfort in the chest that can be a symptom of many different conditions.
shortness of breath: A sensation of not being able to get enough air.
dizziness: A feeling of lightheadedness or loss of balance.
exertion: Physical activity or effort that increases heart rate and breathing.
cough: A reflex action to clear your airways of mucus and irritants.
sore throat: Pain or irritation in the throat that can occur with or without swallowing.
runny nose: A discharge of mucus from the nasal passages.
palpitations: Feelings or sensations that your heart is pounding or racing.
swelling: An abnormal enlargement of a body part or area.
weight loss: A decrease in body weight that is not intentional can be a symptom of disease.
weight gain: An increase in body weight which may be a symptom of illness or medication effect.
biopsy: A medical test involving the removal of tissue to examine for disease.
CT scan: A diagnostic imaging procedure that uses a combination of X-rays and computer technology.
MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging, a technique that uses magnetic fields to produce detailed images of the body.
ultrasound: A medical test that uses high-frequency sound waves to capture live images from inside the body.
X-ray: A quick, painless test that produces images of the structures inside your body, especially bones.
type 2 diabetes: A chronic metabolic disease where the body becomes resistant to insulin, leading to elevated blood glucose levels.
chest: The area of the body between the neck and the abdomen, containing the heart, lungs, and other vital structures.
BP: Blood pressure, the force of circulating blood on the walls of the arteries, measured in millimeters of mercury (mmHg).
HR: Heart rate, the number of heartbeats per minute, indicating cardiovascular status.
RR: Respiratory rate, the number of breaths taken per minute, used to assess breathing and lung function.
Temp: Body temperature, a measure of the body's internal heat, indicating overall health status.
Physical examination: A clinical assessment performed by a medical professional to evaluate the patient’s overall health and detect any signs of disease.
Laboratory results: Results from medical tests performed on samples such as blood or urine, providing information about a patient’s health status.
statin: A class of medications used to lower cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease.
treadmill stress test: A diagnostic test that monitors heart activity and blood flow during exercise, used to assess for coronary artery disease.
troponin: A protein found in heart muscle that is measured to assess for heart injury or damage.
ecg: A test that records the heart's electrical activity to detect arrhythmias and other cardiac conditions.
sinus rhythm: A normal heart rhythm originating from the sinoatrial node.
ECG: Electrocardiogram, a test that measures the electrical activity of the heart.
eeg: Electroencephalogram, a test used to evaluate the electrical activity in the brain.
cbc: Complete Blood Count, a blood test used to evaluate overall health and detect disorders.
lipid profile: A blood test that measures lipids — fats and fatty substances used as a source of energy.
blood glucose: A test measuring the amount of sugar in your blood.
HbA1c: A blood test that reflects average blood glucose levels over the past 3 months.
creatinine: A blood test that helps evaluate kidney function.
BUN: Blood Urea Nitrogen test used to assess kidney function.
liver function test: A group of blood tests that provide information about the state of your liver.
thyroid function test: Tests used to check the function of your thyroid gland.
oxygen saturation: A measure of how much oxygen the blood is carrying as a percentage of the maximum it could carry.
blood pressure: The pressure of circulating blood against the walls of blood vessels.
pulse rate: The number of times your heart beats per minute.
temperature: The measure of the body’s thermal state, important for detecting fever or hypothermia.
IV fluids: Liquids given to a patient through a vein to treat dehydration or deliver medication.
antibiotics: Drugs used to treat bacterial infections.
vaccination: The administration of a vaccine to help the immune system develop protection.
oxygen therapy: Treatment that provides extra oxygen to help breathing.
dialysis: A treatment that removes waste products and excess fluid from the blood when kidneys fail.
surgery: A medical procedure involving an incision with instruments performed to repair damage or treat disease.
chemotherapy: A type of cancer treatment that uses drugs to destroy cancer cells.
radiation therapy: A cancer treatment that uses high doses of radiation to kill cancer cells.
physical therapy: Treatment to help patients improve movement and manage pain.
mental health counseling: A service to help individuals cope with mental or emotional issues.
rehabilitation: Therapy that helps restore skills and normal life after illness or injury.
allergy: An immune response to a substance that’s normally harmless.
infection: The invasion and multiplication of microorganisms in body tissues.
inflammation: The body’s response to injury or infection, causing redness, swelling, and pain.
wound: An injury that breaks the skin or other body tissues.
burn: An injury caused by heat, chemicals, electricity, or radiation.
dehydration: A condition that occurs when you lose more fluids than you take in.
edema: Swelling caused by excess fluid trapped in the body's tissues.
bleeding: The loss of blood from the circulatory system.
shock: A critical condition brought on by the sudden drop in blood flow through the body.
hypoxia: A condition in which there is insufficient oxygen in the tissues.
hyperglycemia: A condition where blood sugar levels are too high.
hypoglycemia: A condition where blood sugar levels are too low.
tachycardia: A fast heart rate, typically over 100 beats per minute.
bradycardia: A slow heart rate, typically fewer than 60 beats per minute.
cyanosis: A bluish discoloration of the skin due to poor circulation or low oxygen levels.
jaundice: Yellowing of the skin and eyes due to high bilirubin levels.
itching: An irritating sensation that causes a desire to scratch.
numbness: Loss of sensation or feeling in a part of the body.
tingling: A prickling or stinging sensation often referred to as 'pins and needles.'
confusion: A state of being disoriented or having difficulty understanding surroundings or information.
delirium: Sudden severe confusion due to rapid changes in brain function.
coma: A deep state of prolonged unconsciousness.
male: A biological sex typically characterized by the presence of XY chromosomes.
age: A numerical expression of how long a person has lived, often relevant in clinical risk assessment.
female: A biological sex typically characterized by the presence of XX chromosomes.
metformin: A medication used to treat type 2 diabetes by lowering blood sugar levels.
insulin: A hormone used as a medication to treat high blood sugar in diabetes.
aspirin: A medication used to reduce pain, fever, or inflammation.
atorvastatin: A medication used to lower cholesterol and reduce the risk of heart disease.
lisinopril: A medication used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure.
amoxicillin: A penicillin antibiotic used to treat a wide variety of bacterial infections.
omeprazole: A medication used to treat stomach issues like acid reflux and ulcers.
paracetamol: A common pain reliever and fever reducer.
ibuprofen: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain, inflammation, and fever.
salbutamol: A medication that relaxes the muscles in the airways and increases airflow to the lungs.
warfarin: An anticoagulant used to prevent blood clots.
clopidogrel: A blood thinner used to prevent strokes and heart attacks.
furosemide: A diuretic used to reduce fluid retention in conditions like heart failure.
hydrochlorothiazide: A diuretic used to treat high blood pressure and swelling due to fluid buildup.
prednisone: A corticosteroid drug used to treat inflammation and autoimmune conditions.
azithromycin: An antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections.
doxycycline: An antibiotic used to treat infections and acne.
morphine: A strong opioid used to treat severe pain.
diazepam: A medication used to treat anxiety, muscle spasms, and seizures.
ondansetron: A medication used to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy or surgery.
angioplasty: A procedure to restore blood flow through the artery.
bypass surgery: A procedure to improve blood flow to the heart by bypassing blocked arteries.
laparoscopy: A surgical procedure using small incisions and a camera to view organs.
colonoscopy: A procedure to examine the inner lining of the large intestine.
endoscopy: A procedure using a flexible tube to examine the digestive tract.
cesarean section: A surgical procedure used to deliver a baby through incisions in the abdomen and uterus.
mastectomy: Surgical removal of one or both breasts.
thoracotomy: Surgical incision into the chest wall.
tracheostomy: Surgical creation of an opening in the trachea to assist breathing.
cardiology: The branch of medicine dealing with disorders of the heart and blood vessels.
neurology: The medical specialty concerned with disorders of the nervous system.
oncology: The branch of medicine that specializes in the diagnosis and treatment of cancer.
pediatrics: The branch of medicine dealing with children and their diseases.
gynecology: The medical practice dealing with the health of the female reproductive system.
obstetrics: The field of study concentrated on pregnancy, childbirth, and the postpartum period.
dermatology: The branch of medicine dealing with the skin and its diseases.
psychiatry: The branch of medicine focused on the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of mental disorders.
orthopedics: The branch of medicine concerned with the musculoskeletal system.
nephrology: The study and treatment of kidney diseases.
gastroenterology: The branch of medicine focused on the digestive system and its disorders.
pulmonology: The medical specialty dealing with diseases involving the respiratory tract.
endocrinology: The branch of medicine dealing with the endocrine system, its diseases, and hormones.
rheumatology: The study of rheumatic diseases involving joints and connective tissues.
hematology: The branch of medicine concerned with blood and blood disorders.
infectious disease: The branch of medicine that deals with infections of all types.
emergency medicine: The medical specialty concerned with care for undifferentiated, unscheduled patients.
general surgery: A surgical specialty that focuses on abdominal organs, breast, skin, and soft tissue surgery.
urology: The branch of medicine focused on the urinary tract system and the male reproductive organs.
insomnia: A sleep disorder in which you have trouble falling and/or staying asleep.
syncope: A temporary loss of consciousness usually related to insufficient blood flow to the brain.
hematuria: The presence of blood in the urine.
proteinuria: The presence of abnormal quantities of protein in the urine, which may indicate kidney disease.
orthopnea: Shortness of breath that occurs when lying flat.
paralysis: The loss of the ability to move (and sometimes to feel) in part or most of the body.
paresis: A condition of muscular weakness caused by nerve damage or disease.
cyanotic heart disease: A group of congenital heart defects that result in low oxygen levels in the blood.
clubbing: A physical sign characterized by bulbous enlargement of the ends of one or more fingers or toes.
ascites: An accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, causing abdominal swelling.
pallor: Paleness of the skin, often due to anemia.
hyperkalemia: Elevated potassium levels in the blood.
hypokalemia: Low potassium levels in the blood.
hypernatremia: An elevated sodium level in the blood.
hyponatremia: A low sodium level in the blood.
acidosis: An excessively acid condition of the body fluids or tissues.
alkalosis: An excessively alkaline condition of the body fluids or tissues.
AGE: A numerical expression of how long a person has lived, often relevant in clinical risk assessment.
SEX: A biological sex typically characterized by the presence of XX (female) or XY (male) chromosomes.
CLINICAL_EVENT: A significant occurrence in the patient’s medical timeline, such as admission, discharge, or surgery.
NONBIOLOGICAL_LOCATION: A location relevant in a clinical setting but not part of the human body (e.g., hospitals).
SEVERITY: The intensity or seriousness of a disease, symptom, or condition.
BIOLOGICAL_STRUCTURE: A component of human anatomy or physiology.
SIGN_SYMPTOM: A physical or mental feature indicating a disease.
HISTORY: A past or ongoing condition or risk factor relevant to clinical care.
DIAGNOSTIC_PROCEDURE: A test or process to determine the nature of a disease.
LAB_VALUE: A measured result from a lab test providing health insights.
MEDICATION: A substance used for medical treatment or prevention.
DETAILED_DESCRIPTION: Contextual information about a medical device, action, or test.
